entry.title: cc muted
entry.content:
I’m sharing my custom Classic Chrome fujifilm simulation called CC Muted. It’s based on Classic Chrome.

Here’s the recipe.

Film Simulation: Classic Chrome Grain Effect: Off Color Chrome Effect: Off Color Chrome FX Blue: Off White Balance: Auto Dynamic Range: DR400 D Range Priority: Off Tone Curve: H -1, S +1 Color: -33 Sharpness: +1 Hign ISO NR: 0 Clarity: 0
entry.summary: I’m sharing my custom Classic Chrome fujifilm simulation called CC Muted. It’s based on Classic Chrome.

entry.title: noir
entry.content:
I’m sharing by black and white fujifilm simulation called Noir. It’s based on Acros +R with DR set to 400.

Here’s the recipe.

Film Simulation: Across + R Monochromatic Color: WC 0, MG 0 Grain Effect: Off Color Chrome Effect: Off Color Chrome FX Blue: Off White Balance: Auto Dynamic Range: DR400 D Range Priority: Off Tone Curve: H 0, S 0 Sharpness: 0 Hign ISO NR: 0 Clarity: 0
entry.summary: I’m sharing by black and white fujifilm simulation called Noir. It’s based on Acros +R with DR set to 400.

entry.title: viltrox 28mm f4.5 af
entry.content:
I purchased a pancake lens from Viltrox. It’a 28m lens which is a 40mm equivalent on full frame. It comes with a fixed aperture at f4.5 with autofocus. It’s sharp in the center as well as in the edges. There’s a little bit of vignetting on the edges and some flare if you shoot at certain angles at the sun. It’s not quite up to par with the other Viltrox 27mm f1.2 that I own, but it’s super lightweight lens and easy to carry around. It’s perfect lens for street photography if you just want to snap pictures randomly without lugging a heavy lens.

It does struggle a little bit with focusing. You may have to hold your camera steady for a few seconds to nail down the focus. Otherwise, it’s a fun little lens for just $99. I got mine at a discount at $79 that’s why I jumped at the chance. Since the lens is a fixed aperture at f4.5, it will struggle some at night. It’s not totally impossible. You just have to be steady. I’m so used to f1.2 that I forget sometimes other lenses are much slower. So, give it a try if you are looking for portability.

If you’re looking something more with a better quality lens and better focusing and less flare, try the other Viltrox lens that I own, which is the Viltrox 27mm f1.2. Just be mindful of the size and weight. I don’t mind at all. I took it to Europe for 2 weeks and I didn’t find it cumbersome.
entry.summary: I purchased a pancake lens from Viltrox. It’a 28m lens which is a 40mm equivalent on full frame. It comes with a fixed aperture at f4.5 with autofocus. It’s sharp in the center as well as in the edges. There’s a little bit of vignetting on the edges and some flare if you shoot at certain angles at the sun. It’s not quite up to par with the other Viltrox 27mm f1.2 that I own, but it’s super lightweight lens and easy to carry around. It’s perfect lens for street photography if you just want to snap pictures randomly without lugging a heavy lens.

entry.title: list file types
entry.content:
How to list file types in the current directory.

#!/bin/bash
fileTypes=("/*.NEF" "/*.JPG")
for i in "${fileTypes[@]}" ; do
  echo $i
done
entry.summary: How to list file types in the current directory.

entry.title: viltrox 27mm f1.2
entry.content:
Just started shooting on a Viltrox 27mm f1.2.

Here are pros and cons.

Pros:

  • sharp all around from 1.2 all the way to f11 before defraction takes over
  • no barrel or pin cushion distortion
  • no chromatic abberation

Cons:

  • heavy lens especially if fitted on a smaller camera
  • vignetting at f1.2. it goes away at around f4.
  • little bit of flare when shot directly at a light

Otherwise, fantastic lens with super sharp results.
entry.summary: Just started shooting on a Viltrox 27mm f1.2.

entry.title: coffee grind settings
entry.content:
Listed below are my espresso settings for the different coffee brands on the Breville Barista Express. Double shots are always 17 grams while single shots are only 8.5 grams. I use the Breville Smart Grinder to dial in the shots and make slight adjustments as needed.

Here are the grind settings:

Coffee Grind #
stauff’s baba budan 6
cafe cubano roast 6
heirloom fire poppy blend 8
stauff’s breakfast 6
crimson cup dark reign 5
goodsam connected day 8
beast dark roast 4
brioso espresso blend 8
roaming goat espresso blend 8
lifeboost emboldened dark roast 6
stauff’s peru 10
stauff’s cerrado 10

Updated October 22, 2025.
entry.summary: Listed below are my espresso settings for the different coffee brands on the Breville Barista Express. Double shots are always 17 grams while single shots are only 8.5 grams. I use the Breville Smart Grinder to dial in the shots and make slight adjustments as needed.

entry.title: ffmpeg convert mk4 to mp4
entry.content:
Here’s a simple ffmpeg command to convert from mk4 to mp4 videos.

ffmpeg -i coffee.mkv -codec copy coffee.mp4

It works on other formats as well such as mov, wmv, avi, mkv, webm to name just a few.
entry.summary: Here’s a simple ffmpeg command to convert from mk4 to mp4 videos.

entry.title: tmux on macos iterm2 vscode
entry.content:
The other day I started using tmux terminal emulator on my mac desktop. I’m using iterm2 inside Visual Code Editor. If you’re not familiar with tmux, it contains sessions. Inside each session, you can have multiple windows. Inside each window, you can have multiple panes. Switching across sessions, windows or panes is easy. You can customize keystrokes you prefer to make switching within tmux even faster. I modified my tmux configuration by creating a file called ~/.tmux.conf.

Here’s my setup.

# Status bar colors
set -g default-terminal "screen-256color"
set-window-option -g xterm-keys on
set -g status-bg default
set -g status-fg default

# Change prefix
unbind C-b
set-option -g prefix `
bind ` send-prefix

# Weather
set -g status-interval 120
WEATHER='#(curl -s wttr.in/Hilliard\?format\="%%l:+%%c%%20%%t%%20%%f%%20%%h%%20%%w%%20&period=60&u")'
set -g status-right " tmux iTerm2 MacOS | $WEATHER | %b %d %Y %l:%M %p  "
set -g status-right-length 130

# Mouse mode
set -g mouse on

# Alt-arrows
bind -n M-Left select-pane -L
bind -n M-Right select-pane -R
bind -n M-Up select-pane -U
bind -n M-Down select-pane -D

# Split keys
bind-key v split-window -h
bind-key h split-window -v

# Shift arrows
bind -n S-Left previous-window
bind -n S-Right next-window

# Swap windows
bind-key -n C-S-Left swap-window -t -1; select-window -t -1
bind-key -n C-S-Right swap-window -t +1; select-window -t +1

# Sync panes
bind-key y set-window-option synchronize-panes\; display-message "Toggle syncronize mode."

# Reload tmux config
bind r source-file ~/.tmux.conf\; display-message "Load tmux configuration."
entry.summary: The other day I started using tmux terminal emulator on my mac desktop. I’m using iterm2 inside Visual Code Editor. If you’re not familiar with tmux, it contains sessions. Inside each session, you can have multiple windows. Inside each window, you can have multiple panes. Switching across sessions, windows or panes is easy. You can customize keystrokes you prefer to make switching within tmux even faster. I modified my tmux configuration by creating a file called ~/.tmux.conf.

entry.title: linux mint 22 xia
entry.content:
I upgraded my Linux Mint desktop to the latest Mint 22 Xia.

So far so good. Subtle differences, but can’t see major changes.

The current version is now supported until the year 2029.
